entry.title: Shippeo Real-Time Visibility for SAP Business Network Global Track and Trace: An SAP Endorsed App
entry.content:
Shippeo's real-time transportation visibility data-as-a-service is now an SAP Endorsed App available on SAP Store for integration with the SAP Business Network Global Track and Trace solution (press release: English, Fran√ßais, Deutsch).  This advancement provides SAP customers with real-time shipment execution data to support supply chain predictability, resilience, and sustainability, reassured by Shippeo‚Äôs leadership in data quality when it comes to tracking completeness and ETA accuracy.

This offering extends the reach of SAP Business Network Global Track and Trace by providing multimodal visibility for shipments with data from Shippeo's global network that connects with over 228,000 carriers and 1,100 TMS, WMS, telematics, and ELD systems, covering road, ocean, and parcel transportation.

What does this mean for your business?  

Simplicity in gaining just the high-quality visibility data that you need. 

  • Real-Time Visibility: The service provides real-time visibility for Full Truck Loads (FTL), Less than Truck Loads (LTL), and ocean containers (FCL, LCL). This includes geolocation updates and actual or geofenced milestones for tracking movements on road or at sea.
  • High Quality Data: Estimated Times of Arrival (ETAs) are generated using predictive AI, adapting to real-time traffic, weather, road conditions, and driver hours of service regulations. Shippeo guarantees high accuracy for road delay predictions, as well as high accuracy and completeness for ocean ETA predictions up to 30 days before arrival.
  • Tracking Completeness: Shippeo commits to high tracking rates for all shipments sent for tracking for road and ocean transportation, and high completeness of ocean container tracking and milestones.  
  • Carrier Integration: Carrier integration is managed by Shippeo, which supports multiple tracking solutions including telematics, TMS, and mobile apps. Shippeo commits to onboarding most carriers within 30 days for telematics and 60 days for TMS integration, once the connection request is received.  The integration of Shippeo‚Äôs data-as-a-service into SAP Business Network Global Track and Trace is standardized. 

As an SAP Endorsed App, Shippeo‚Äôs solution has completed premium certification by SAP, which includes in-depth testing and assessments. This partnership aims to enhance supply chain resilience and responsiveness for the inbound and outbound logistics of shippers in all industries.

entry.title: Supply Chain Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508
entry.content:
The SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release is here and delivers a broad range of innovations and enhancements across core business processes, focusing on greater automation, improved user experience, and deeper integration to help organizations run more efficiently in a cloud-first environment. Don't miss the highlights blog by Bert Schulze to find out more about the top innovations across the cloud ERP, or find out about the top AI & next-gen ERP features in this post by Yannick Peterschmitt.

With the supply chain specialists and logistics maestros in mind - this blog post dials in on the latest supply chain management features being rolled out in and around the 2508 release. With this release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, supply chain management takes another step forward in agility, intelligence, and integration. This update introduces a range of enhancements designed to optimize end-to-end processes, improve real-time visibility, and support faster decision-making across logistics and operations. Whether you're focused on inventory, transport, production, or delivery, the 2508 release brings innovative features that align with today's demand for resilient and sustainable supply chains. Check out the release video below for the quick summary of selected features, or read on below for more detail and some comprehensive E2E demos!

 

Core Logistics Topics

We'll kick things off with the latest core logistics features release in 2508, designed to enhance your fundamental supply chain execution and planning processes.


Inventory Management
Support for Copied Movement Types in SAP Fiori Apps for Goods movement

Flexibility to adapt business processes is a vital aspect of a dynamic supply chain, and custom movement types in SAP S/4HANA Cloud offer just that. These custom adaptations of standard movement types serve to bridge gaps where predefined scenarios may not meet particular business needs, allowing tailor-made solutions for unique business requirements. The SAP FIORI apps which support custom movement types have been extended to include Manage stock (F1062), Transfer Stock ‚Äì In Plant (F1061) and Transfer Stock ‚Äì Cross Plan (F1957).

One prominent use case for custom movement types arises when there‚Äôs a need to post goods movements to different General Ledger (GL) account determinations. While standard movement types seamlessly integrate with key SAP FIORI apps for goods movement, setting up a custom movement type involves a simple two-step process: first, copy an existing standard movement type in your configuration environment, assigning it a new character key starting with 9, x, y, or z, while adding any additional necessary details. The next step is to implement the custom Business Add-In (BAdI) MMIM_GR4XY_PROVIDE_DATA. This facilitates the availability of this newly created movement type alongside standard options in the supported FIORI apps, allowing users the flexibility to select the movement type that best fits their operational needs. This approach not only maximizes the system‚Äôs adaptability but also ensures streamlined and efficient management of specialized business processes.

For a step-by-step description of the implementing this process, check out this blog post.


(fig: Custom movement types displayed in Transfer Stock ‚Äì In Plant)

New FIORI App - Manage Physical Inventory Document Items

In Inventory Management, a key theme of the 2508 release is the strategic modernization of the user experience to boost performance and analytical capabilities. With the 2508 release, we introduce the new app ‚ÄúManage Physical Inventory document Items‚Äù (F8634) as a successor to transaction MI20 ‚ÄúProcess physical inventory count results‚Äù, which has been deprecated. The experience switch is enabled on both apps, enabling users with the correct authorizations to switch between them with ease. The new app provides a clearer overview of physical inventory tasks, directly in the list view saving users time. The new app‚Äôs functionality doesn‚Äôt stop there; it empowers you to fine-tune your workflow through customization options. For instance, adding fields such as storage bin information can streamline precise material location management. Moreover, with enhanced filtering capabilities, you can now delve deeper into your data, allowing for a more nuanced analysis of inventory differences. With these improvements, transitioning to the Manage Physical Inventory Item List (F8634) app not only future-proofs your inventory operations but also enriches the way you interact with your inventory data.

Support for Barcode Scanning for Additional Goods Issues (Project / Asset)

A further new feature in inventory management ‚Äì the "Manage Stock" app has been enhanced with barcode scanning for goods movements for both project stock and assets. New movement types for this stock have been introduced to streamline and optimize your inventory management processes. Efficiency gains come with the capability to leverage composite barcode scanning within the app. Users can select the new stock change options for goods issue projects or assets in the manage stock app, then assign the related WBS element or asset or sub-asset number respectively. This enhancement translates to faster and more efficient processing of inventory adjustments, reducing not just the margin for error but also the time spent managing inventory tasks. Overall, these updates are set to greatly enhance stock management workflows, making them not only more efficient but also more aligned with contemporary business needs.

Cross-Plant Transfer Posting with Item Lines

Item lists are a collection of material items that you can process together in warehouse or inventory processes. Whilst this is a familiar feature, with 2508 we have expanded where item lists are deployed to enhance inventory processes and introduce them to the ‚ÄúTransfer Stock ‚Äì Cross Plan‚Äù application. Here, it is now possible to create a list of multiple items for stock transfer, enabling users to post items in one step and on one material document. This provides greater visibility as you see all transferred items in one list across plants and improves efficiency when checking movement history for several materials on one list.

Extensibility Updates

Enhancing process flexibility, this release introduces new extensibility options for material reservation applications. Businesses can now add custom fields to the user interfaces and underlying business logic for creating, changing, and displaying reservations. This allows companies to capture and process specific information relevant to their unique operational needs directly within the reservation document. For example, a business could add a field to track a project code or a specific reason for the reservation, improving data richness, enhancing reporting, and ensuring that custom process requirements are met without complex workarounds.

Handling Unit Management

Key to managing packaging, tracking and handling goods throughout your supply chain, we also have some updates to Handling Unit Management functionality. With this release, we introduce two key enhancements to Handling Units APIs.

Assign Serial Numbers to Existing Handling Units

A key innovation in this release is the enhancement of the Handling Unit (HU) OData API, which now supports the assignment of serial numbers to already created handling units‚Äîa critical capability that was previously missing. This enhancement addresses a functional gap left by previous API operations that only supported packing and posting goods receipt for production orders. Now, before a goods receipt is posted, serial numbers can be assigned to HUs via the API, streamlining processes where HUs are prepared in advance. This capability ensures better alignment with manufacturing and warehouse workflows where serialization is required before physical goods receipt.

The updated API enables serial number assignment through two supported scenarios: either by generating serial numbers automatically at production order creation (based on the serial number profile), or by receiving them from an external system via API communication. The API intelligently checks whether a production order already includes serial numbers and defaults to these when assigning to HUs, ensuring data consistency. This innovation not only supports developer extensibility and integration flexibility but also significantly enhances traceability and compliance in serialized environments‚Äîespecially in regulated industries.

Enhanced Security for Production Supply Area Data

To strengthen integration security, the Production Supply Area (PSA) OData API now supports OAuth 2.0 authentication, aligning with modern SAP security protocols and standards. This enhancement ensures a more secure, token-based authorization process, enabling third-party applications to access SAP S/4HANA Cloud resources without exposing sensitive credentials in the payload. OAuth 2.0 improves trust and compliance for integrations, especially in multi-system landscapes where security and granular access control are critical.

This update also improves connectivity with SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), making it easier to securely link external applications to SAP S/4HANA Cloud for PSA-related data access. Applications can now request specific scopes of access to user data, supporting role-based security and limiting unnecessary data exposure. With this change, customers gain more controlled, secure, and scalable integration patterns for managing production supply data across platforms.


Delivery Management

RAP events are standardized notifications that signal changes in business objects, enabling flexible and loosely coupled extensions in SAP S/4HANA Cloud. With the latest innovation, RAP events are now available for outbound delivery, inbound delivery, and customer returns delivery, empowering developers working with embedded extensibility (Developer Extensibility) to enhance their projects directly on-stack. You can implement custom logic to consume events such as Created, Changed, or Deleted for these delivery documents, as well as more granular events like Picking Status Changed or Item Created for outbound deliveries. This makes it possible to react instantly to delivery-related changes in your extensions built with the ABAP environment, while leveraging standardized events that increase development efficiency and consistency across solutions


Order Promising

Conversational Backorder Processing with Joule (Beta)

Imagine running a complex backorder processing (BOP) run by simply having a conversation. With the 2508 release, this is now a reality! Introduced initially as a BETA feature, from CFD release 2508.2, all users with a base license of Joule can leverage AI to automate BOP checks and processing.

Using simple, natural language commands in a chat, you can check stock situations and initiate a BOP run. For example, you can tell Joule you want to run BOP for a specific product and plant. In the background, Joule will prompt for which strategy you wish to implement with the default selection of ‚Äúimprove‚Äù, it creates the necessary BOP segment and variant, and processes the run‚Äîskipping multiple manual steps and app-toggling. This is a fantastic leap forward in simplifying a powerful process, and we are excited to hear how adopting this feature has enhanced your experience!

 

 

Display Product Availability Enhancements

With the 2508 release, we bid farewell to jumping between various transactions when seeking a comprehensive overview of product availability. The new Display Product Availability Fiori app is here to modernize and simplify your experience. Instead of scattered views, you now get all relevant availability information in a single, intuitive three-panel layout. At a glance, you see a high-level summary of available quantities, a detailed drill-down of MRP elements such as stocks and requirements, and a clear "Scope of Check" panel showing which supply and demand elements are included. With this release, the app now also includes the Analyze Product Availability feature. This allows you to dive deeper into product availability at the plant level. You can easily analyze product availability by selecting the plant you want to review and the app gives you a clear overview of confirmations, showing why certain quantities are available on specific dates and how concurrent demands impact stock or receipts. This makes it easier to respond to customer needs and share insights with stakeholders.

To dig deeper, you can drill down on MRP elements, adjust the date range to see planned changes, or view the scope of check to understand exactly which stocks, receipts, and requirements are considered. Horizon settings further explain why available quantities may appear positive, zero, or even negative. By surfacing these factors in one place, the app provides transparency and confidence in managing product availability.

See the new enhancements in the below demo video:

 

What‚Äôs more, with CFD release 2508.1, we extend these MRP features beyond the plant category to also account for storage locations. Conduct analysis and drill down on the same elements based on storage location with the same simplified UI panels within the Display Product Availability app.

Activating ATP Check for Subcontracting Outbound Delivery Creation

Many customers working with the subcontracting purchasing process face a key challenge: preventing outbound delivery notes from being created when there is no stock available. In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud release 2508, we address this challenge by enabling ATP checks for subcontracting outbound delivery creation. Until now, the ATP (Available-to-Promise) check was not triggered for subcontracting deliveries, meaning delivery notes could still be generated even if stock levels are zero.

This gap can create inefficiencies, as users may be instructed to pick items that simply aren‚Äôt available in the warehouse. For companies which outsource parts of their manufacturing through subcontractors, accurate stock management is essential to keep production flowing. It is critical that only available and ready-to-pick stock is passed into subcontracting deliveries. Without validation, discrepancies between SAP and the actual warehouse stock can lead to delays, wasted effort, and disruptions in the supply chain.

By enabling configuration of the ATP check flag in the 2508 release, ATP  check can be enforced for subcontracting deliveries, ensuring that stock availability is validated before outbound deliveries are created. The result is clear: consistent order promising across the supply chain, improved accuracy, and smoother end-to-end operations.

 

Transportation Management

Stock transfer with delivery (BME) with warehouse management and transportation management(outbound)

One of the key challenges for supply chain specialists is managing outbound processes efficiently while ensuring seamless coordination between warehouse and transportation operations. Expanding on the outbound process defined in scope item ‚Äústock transfer with delivery (BME)‚Äù, with the 2502.3 release, we integrate both warehouse management and transportation management to streamline stock transfer orders end to end.

Customers can now create intra-company Stock Transport Orders (STOs) that automatically trigger Freight Unit (FU) creation in TM and generate Outbound Deliveries, which are processed through WM for picking, packing, and loading. A key new feature is dynamic delivery splitting‚Äîif not all handling units (HUs) can be loaded, the system automatically creates a new outbound delivery for the remaining goods. Additionally, TM now supports stock transfers from WM-managed locations, and includes batch-managed material data in freight documents. These updates provide customers with a fully integrated, automated logistics flow that improves supply chain visibility, operational efficiency, and flexibility‚Äîespecially in dynamic warehouse and transport environments.

 

Enabling key user extensibility of freight document user interfaces

This feature introduces the flexibility to adapt the user interface of applications based on Web Dynpro ABAP (WDA)and Floorplan Manager (FPM), giving your business greater control over how classic application screens look and function. It addresses the common challenge of rigid UIs by empowering key users and technical teams to configure freight document interfaces‚Äîsuch as adding or removing fields, adjusting layouts, or rearranging elements‚Äîto match specific business needs. The feature allows you to adjust the structure of main UI pages, including the sequence and titles of tabs, as well as tailor the content of specific areas‚Äîfor example, changing the order of fields, updating field labels, or hiding elements that aren‚Äôt relevant. With this update, we‚Äôre delivering clear value in supporting the customizing of UIs which better reflect your company‚Äôs specific use cases and processes, enabling users to interact with the applications more productively.

 

Warehouse Management

Keeping up with the Suite-First strategy, in 2508 much has been done to ensure that Warehouse Management functionality supports all scope items and process variations available within SAP S/4HANA Cloud ERP. Take a look in more detail in this blog by Christian Ries. Below, we‚Äôll focus on a few new features we want to highlight in particular.

Stock Removal Strategy for direct goods movement postings (EWM)

A much requested feature which we‚Äôre happy to roll out to customers, the Post Goods Movement app now includes a new button that triggers the stock removal strategy. This automatically determines the optimal storage bin, handling unit, and batch or serial number when posting a direct goods issue. Available for goods issue postings in manufacturing orders and reservations, this feature streamlines the process by aligning with your stock removal strategy to select the best storage bin. The result is greater efficiency and accuracy when posting goods issues, reducing manual effort and errors. Specifically designed for goods issue of production components, this enhancement ensures that the right stock is used at the right time‚Äîsupporting faster, more reliable production execution.

Summarized JIT Calls 

This feature enables efficient handling of outbound deliveries that reference summarized Just-in-Time (JIT) calls within Warehouse Management. By integrating seamlessly with JIT processes, it ensures that deliveries comply with configured underdelivery and overdelivery tolerances. Leveraging the built-in warehouse management capabilities‚Äîsuch as picking, packing, staging, and loading‚Äîyou can now handle outbound processing of summarized JIT calls (scope item 2EM) more effectively. Outbound deliveries with JIT references can be easily selected and processed within warehouse management, improving efficiency, accuracy, and reliability, while directly benefiting customers through more consistent and timely deliveries.

 

Integrating Extended Warehouse Management


Many of our customers have sophisticated supply chains and warehouse processes which involve central hubs and different satellite entities. With 2508, we are excited to roll out an integration scenario which will make managing such a set up much simpler. With the new communication scenario, Logistics - S/4HANA Extended Warehouse Management Integration (SAP_COM_0A58), you can now integrate a decentralized Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) system in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition with your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. This integration provides essential services to distribute and maintain inbound and outbound deliveries across hybrid landscapes. This helps your organization leverage existing EWM investments while expanding your cloud footprint, ensuring seamless data flow for critical delivery processes.

In-house Repair with Warehouse Management

A common challenge in after-sales service is managing the logistics of returning repaired products back to customers quickly and efficiently. With the 2508 release, we have enhanced the in-house repair process (scope item 3XK) by integrating warehouse management. This should streamline this process enabling companies to more efficiently define and execute their in-house repair workflows.

The process begins when a returned product is received and logged into the warehouse, where serial numbers are verified and the item is moved to a clarification zone for inspection. If an in-house repair is needed, a follow-up activity is created, ensuring the right material and serial number are tracked through the repair cycle. Once the product is fixed, an outbound delivery order is generated, and warehouse management takes over again to pick, pack, stage, and load the item for shipment back to the customer.



By leveraging warehouse management capabilities, organizations can optimize every step of the return‚Äîfrom picking and packing the repaired product to staging and loading it for shipment. This ensures accuracy, reduces manual effort, and speeds up turnaround times, ultimately improving the customer experience while driving efficiency in logistics operations. See the full process in the below End-to-End demo.


Summary

The 2508 release highlights in the supply chain management area of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition should help optimize your supply chain and logistics processes. entry.title: 5C Framework for SAP Integrated Business Planning Data Validation Strategy
entry.content:
Why Data Quality in SAP IBP?

The success of SAP IBP hinges on the availability of quality data from all relevant sources across the organization. Without this foundation of high-quality data, the collaborative and cross-functional nature of IBP will be severely hampered, leading to flawed insights, poor decisions, and an ineffective planning process that fails to deliver the expected business benefits.

Therefore, organizations implementing SAP IBP must prioritize data quality initiatives as a critical component of their implementation and ongoing operations to ensure that they can leverage the full potential of the integrated planning platform. This often involves establishing data governance processes, data quality and validation routines, and ongoing monitoring of data quality across all the heterogeneous systems and departments.

I, as an IBP solution architect and consultant, have seen data quality impact on various functions and across all levels.

1. Accurate Forecasting and Demand Planning:

  • IBP heavily relies on accurate demand forecasts to plan production, inventory, and supply chain activities.
  • Poor data quality in historical sales data, market trends, or customer information will lead to inaccurate forecasts, resulting in either overstocking (leading to waste and costs) or understocking (leading to lost sales and customer dissatisfaction).

2. Reliable Supply Planning:

  • Accurate demand forecasts and reliable data on current inventory levels, lead times, and supplier capabilities are essential for effective supply planning.
  • Inaccurate data in these areas can lead to production delays, material shortages, and increased costs.

3. Effective Financial Planning:

  • IBP integrates financial planning with operational plans. Accurate financial data, including costs, revenues, and profitability, is crucial for making sound financial decisions.
  • Poor data quality can lead to inaccurate financial projections and budgets, impacting the overall financial health of the organization.

4. Informed Decision-Making:

  • IBP aims to provide a holistic view of the business, enabling informed decision- making across different departments.
  • If the underlying data is inaccurate, incomplete, or inconsistent, the insights derived from IBP will be flawed, leading to poor strategic and operational decisions.

5. Seamless Collaboration:

  • IBP fosters collaboration among different departments. Consistent and reliable data ensures that all stakeholders are working with the same information, facilitating effective communication and alignment.
  • Data quality issues can create friction and mistrust among teams, hindering the collaborative nature of IBP.

6. Performance Measurement and Improvement:

  •  IBP involves monitoring key performance indicators (KPIs) to track progress and identify areas for improvement.
  • Accurate data is essential for measuring performance accurately and identifying the root causes of any issues. Poor data quality can lead to misleading performance metrics and ineffective improvement initiatives.

Data quality is paramount for IBP success. Without high quality data, the benefits of IBP cannot be fully realized, and the organization risks making poor decisions that can negatively impact its bottom line and overall performance.

 

5C Framework for SAP IBP Data Validation

The proposed 5Cs are the core traits which determine whether the data is fit for the SAP IBP planning purpose. By adhering to these 5C's, organizations can improve their data quality, leading to more reliable insights, better decision-making, and increased operational efficiency. It is important to note that maintaining high data quality is an ongoing process that requires continuous monitoring and improvement.

  1. Conformity
  2. Consistency
  3. Completeness
  4. Comprehensiveness
  5. Concurrency

Figure 1: 5Cs of Data Quality Framework

1.      Conformity

This aspect of the SAP IBP data quality ensures that data adheres to predefined rules and standards regarding format, type, and size.

  1. Case for the predefined rules: In SAP IBP there are predefined special characters which cannot be used. (Refer to SAP note: 2453887)

Figure 2: SAP Note 2453887 listing restricted characters

b. Case for the format, type, and size: In SAP IBP, each attribute that exists has a format, type and size associated. All the value must comply by the formats, types, and sizes otherwise there is a risk of the job failure with fatal error.

FORMAT TYPESIZE
NVARCHAR (with/without Only Upper Case)  Character Length (max length up to 450)
DECIMAL    18,6
INTEGER      Whole Number
TIMESTAMP        YYYYMMDD hh:mm:ss.000

Table 1: SAP IBP Format Types and Sizes

2.      Consistency

This aspect of the SAP IBP data quality ensures uniformity, coherency, and avoidance of contradictions across different data sources, planning areas, data objects and time periods. Consistency ensures that information is uniform and comparable throughout the organization. However, when SAP IBP receives data from multiple sources such as ERP systems, data warehouses, cloud-based data lakes, third-party systems, home-grown applications, production planning system, transport planning system and planners' Excel sheets, maintaining data consistency becomes key area to focus on. This diversity of data sources, if ignored, can lead to discrepancies in data formats, definitions, and quality, potentially compromising the accuracy of SAP IBP's planning processes.

To ensure consistency in master Data SAP IBP provides some in-build checks which must be configured like attribute checks and mandatory attributes.

Figure 3: IBP Master Data object consistency checks with attribute checks

For IBP transactional data, we can ensure consistency by adding a mandatory attribute from compound master data in planning level for the key figure. Such configuration avoids inconsistent transactional data flowing into the system.

Figure 4: IBP mandatory attribute used in base planning level of key figures

It is important to understand that SAP IBP does not inherently guarantee consistency within object hierarchies such as Product, Customer, and Location hierarchies. Therefore, the Customer and System Integrator's consultants must collaboratively develop a strategy to ensure consistency in parent-child relationships (1:N cardinality) for hierarchical data objects. This proactive approach is crucial for accurate aggregation and disaggregation, enabling effective and actionable insights.

Figure 5: IBP Data Hierarchy with Parent Child relationship

To ensure the correct parent-child relationships, one of the approaches is to extract a parent-child combination in excel sheet and create a pivot table on unique records. All children must have single parent otherwise aggregation and disaggregation will be wrong, leading to wrong planning results.

3.      Completeness

The completeness of data refers to the state where all the necessary and relevant data points required for the specific planning process and the overall IBP framework are present and available within the system. It means that there are no significant gaps or missing pieces of information that hinder the ability to perform accurate analysis, generate reliable plan and make informed decisions.

Figure 6: Incomplete/Broken Supply Network

Figure 6 clearly demonstrates the incompleteness of the data from the supply chain network where capacity data at resource is missing along with a broken network with respect to missing lanes. Such an incomplete dataset will generate improper planning results.

To avoid the incomplete data flowing into the IBP system, we need to develop interfaces outside the IBP system using ABAP validations in SAP S4 or BW4HANA or CIDS to identify the incompleteness and generate a report for correction by clients IT Team / Data Management Team. By using the "Manage Rules for Master Data Maintenance" feature in IBP, we can effectively define the correct "Subnetwork" node and diagnose which node is disrupting the supply chain network. Example: All Location product combinations to pass through following checks updating a corresponding custom attribute which finally impacts the subnetwork.

1.Inbound: Master data rule to check for Location source in Location Source object.

2.Inbound: Master data rule to check source production in Source Production Header object.

3.Outbound: Master data rule to check Ship-from with product combination in Location Source object.

4.Outbound: Master data rule to check Location Product combination in Source Customer object.

5.Outbound: Master data rule to check Location Product combination in production source Item.

* This is just an approach which may differ from project to project and network schema variations.

4.      Comprehensiveness

Data Comprehensiveness refers to the degree to which all the necessary and relevant data required to support the IBP processes, models, and overall planning objectives is available, accessible, and integrated within the IBP system. It goes beyond just having completeness. It entails:

  • Breadth of Data: Having data across all relevant dimensions and business areas that are within the scope of the IBP implementation. This includes data related to sales, demand, supply, inventory, finance, and potentially other relevant areas.
  • Depth of Data: Having data at the appropriate level of detail required for the planning activities, ensuring that data is available for all the products, customers, locations, and other relevant entities that are included in the IBP planning scope.

Figure 7: Data Comprehensiveness covers all the IBP data objects including each attribute

Example for missing comprehensiveness can be missing key attribute values like Lead Times, Lot Sizes, rounding values, Quota split ratios, Cost rates, On-hand Inventory for few combinations only in IBP system. It may cause unreliable planning results. To systematically capture all such cases, IBP custom alerts can be valuable to report missing attributes. Along with this the IBP‚Äôs feature like ‚ÄúDiscover Pattern using Machine Learning‚Äù, ‚ÄúFind Numerical Outliers‚Äù can help identify the completeness gaps.

Figure 8: IBP Feature for data pattern discovery and numeric outliers

5.      Concurrency

Every business executive stives to strike alignment between business strategic planning and execution system. Concurrency in planning and execution represents a paradigm shift from traditional sequential approaches, enabling organizations to adapt dynamically in fast-paced environments. This methodology interweaves planning and action in real time, allowing adjustments based on evolving conditions while maintaining operational continuity. The planning and execution should be coupled like Yin-Yang.

Figure 9: Yin-Yang of Planning and Execution

From IBP planning perspective the concurrency is achieved while keeping it updated with the latest execution data. The execution data represents the latest customer orders, internal goods movements between Plants and RDCs, latest production orders, and vendor related purchase orders are integrated daily or even lesser frequency to IBP. This enables IBP planners to have complete visibility of the execution system, and they can align the plan or coordinate with execution teams to keep working on the same organizational objective.

Conclusive Remarks

At its core, the success of SAP IBP depends entirely on high-quality data. Without a solid foundation of accurate, reliable information, the platform's ability to facilitate collaboration and integrated planning is undermined. This leads to flawed insights, poor decision-making, and ultimately, a failure to deliver the expected business benefits.

Key impacts of poor data quality include:

  • Inaccurate forecasting and supply planning, resulting in issues like over- or under-stocking.

  • Flawed financial planning and projections.

  • Uninformed decisions because the underlying data is inconsistent or incomplete.

  • Friction among teams due to a lack of trust in shared data.

  • Misleading performance metrics, which hinder effective improvement initiatives.

Therefore, prioritizing data quality through robust governance, validation, and monitoring is not just a best practice‚Äîit's essential for organizations to fully leverage SAP IBP's potential. The 5C Validation Framework (Conformity, Consistency, Completeness, Comprehensiveness, Concurrency) provides a core set of traits to ensure data is fit for purpose, leading to more reliable insights and greater operational efficiency.

entry.title: Is Your Traceability Strategy Ready for 2027? Discover SAP Corporate Serialization
entry.content:
Product traceability is no longer just a regulatory requirement; it has become a strategic imperative. Today, it underpins risk management, accelerates recalls, and builds consumer trust in increasingly complex supply chains. A robust traceability strategy safeguards brand integrity and drives competitive advantage in a market that demands transparency.

Historically, industries relied on SAP Auto-ID Infrastructure (AII) and SAP Object Event Repository (OER) on the NetWeaver platform as the standard for traceability, turning compliance into operational efficiency. But with SAP ending mainstream maintenance for NetWeaver applications by 2027, forward-thinking companies must plan their next move.

The strategic path forward is migration to SAP Corporate Serialization. More than an upgrade, it‚Äôs a transformative step that unifies AII and OER capabilities into a modern, integrated platform designed for today‚Äôs global supply chains. This transition future-proofs operations, meets evolving transparency requirements, and positions businesses for sustainable growth.

This article will guide supply chain leaders through this critical shift, addressing the most pressing questions about SAP Corporate Serialization:

  • What is SAP Corporate Serialization?
  • What capabilities does SAP Corporate Serialization offer?
  • What are the use cases of SAP Corporate Serialization?
  • What is the business value of SAP Corporate Serialization?

 

What is SAP Corporate Serialization?

SAP Corporate Serialization is a secure, private cloud-based SaaS solution that layers seamlessly on top of existing SAP ERP systems, consolidating the capabilities of SAP AII and SAP OER into a single, cohesive platform. It provides scalable serialization management, integrating with shop-floor systems and meeting global regulatory requirements.

The solution enables end-to-end visibility across the entire product lifecycle; from subcomponents to finished goods; transforming traceability from static records into a dynamic narrative. It authenticates products, combats counterfeiting, and manages both batch and logistics unit distribution. By unifying serialized data and events across suppliers, manufacturing sites, and customers, and integrating with systems like ERP, WMS, MES, and RFID/barcode technologies, SAP Corporate Serialization captures every event from production to delivery (Figure 1)

Figure 1:- System Landscape with SAP Corporate Serialization

 

What capabilities does SAP Corporate Serialization offer?

1. Central Serial Number Management: Generate flexible alphanumeric, randomized, or product-specific serials and distribute them in bulk, reducing manual effort, ensuring accuracy, and supporting compliance.

2. End-to-End Integration and Extensibility: Connect seamlessly with SAP Business Network, SAP EWM, SAP ECC/S/4HANA, and non-SAP systems (Figure 2), while also extending the solution to accommodate customer-specific requirements and traceability attributes; enhancing operational decision-making and supply chain visibility.

Figure 2: SAP Corporate Serialization Integration Options

3. Automation and Standardization: Automate serialization, reporting, and data exchange; streamlining workflows, enforcing consistent processes, and lowering risk of errors.

4. User Experience and Interfaces Monitoring: Intuitive SAP GUI and FIORI interfaces combined with SAP Application Interface Framework (AIF) monitoring; enabling faster onboarding, real-time transaction oversight, and quick resolution of exceptions.

5. Future-Proof, Cost-Efficient Architecture: Supports GS1, EPCIS, and other formats like IMEI, UID, and UDI. Consolidates legacy AII and OER systems, minimizes customization, and aligns with SAP S/4HANA and industry standards; reducing total cost of ownership while preparing businesses for evolving regulatory and operational demands.

 

What are the use cases of SAP Corporate Serialization?

SAP Corporate Serialization delivers flexible, industry-specific solutions that transform traceability from a compliance requirement into a strategic advantage. In automotive, it tracks EV batteries and safety-critical components throughout production and service lifecycles. Aerospace and defense benefit from full traceability of iUID-marked parts to meet stringent regulatory standards.

Consumer products leverage the platform to authenticate goods, combat counterfeiting, and engage buyers through digital product passports, while managing reusable assets like beverage kegs. In consumer electronics, it ensures serialization of devices, components, and software licenses, supporting traceability, warranty tracking, and fraud prevention. Tobacco and beverage industries use SAP Corporate Serialization to manage serial numbers linked to tax stamps and track premium or returnable products; ensuring compliance, authenticity, and streamlined reuse.

The hi-tech, utilities, and specialty gas sectors gain precise tracking of high-value components, spare parts, and cylinders, improving asset visibility, safety, and operational efficiency. In agribusiness, each pallet or shipment is tagged with a unique serial number, capturing its journey from harvest to delivery; enhancing logistics, inventory accuracy, and supply chain transparency.

Healthcare and medical device companies benefit from UDI compliance and post-sale serialization, linking components to digital service records to optimize lifecycle management, anticipate maintenance, and strengthen customer trust.

Across all these sectors, SAP Corporate Serialization proves its scalability and adaptability, supporting both compliance-driven and value-driven business outcomes, while turning traceability into a driver of efficiency, trust, and growth.

 

What is the business value of SAP Corporate Serialization?

Transitioning to SAP Corporate Serialization is not just about staying supported beyond 2027; it‚Äôs a strategic move that transforms traceability into a driver of efficiency, visibility, and growth. The platform operates in the background like an autopilot, automating serial number management operations, which improving employee productivity and freeing QA, logistics, and customer service teams to focus on exceptions, while providing instant access to service histories.

By centralizing serialized data, it reduces compliance and risk management costs, streamlines QA and RA workflows, and provides fully traceable records for audits. During recalls, affected products or components are identified quickly and precisely, minimizing operational disruption and waste.

Beyond operational gains, SAP Corporate Serialization safeguards brand reputation and drives sales. End-to-end traceability ensures authenticity, combats counterfeiting, and builds consumer trust, while digital experiences like product passports enhance engagement and encourage repeat purchases; protecting both brand and revenue.

Conclusion

The adoption of SAP Corporate Serialization is far more than a system upgrade; it‚Äôs a strategic investment in resilience, transparency, and long-term competitiveness. As the 2027 deadline approaches, the companies that act now will not only secure compliance but also unlock new value through lower costs, greater agility, and stronger consumer trust.

The question is no longer if serialization will redefine your supply chain, but how fast you can position your business to lead. Our team stands ready to partner with you; bringing best practices and proven expertise to ensure a seamless transition and help you capture the full potential of an intelligent product traceability ecosystem.

Learn how leading companies leverage SAP Corporate Serialization to achieve end-to-end product traceability, reduce operational complexity, and drive business resilience.

entry.title: Intelligent Supply Chains in Action: Fujitsu‚Äôs Agentic AI Approach to Global Trade Challenges
entry.content:
Introduction

Across industries, supply chain disruptions have become the new normal. Global manufacturers are navigating a complex web of challenges, including shifting trade policies, volatile energy prices, climate-driven events, and the growing demand for sustainable operations. The systems and strategies that once brought stability now struggle to keep up with this constant change.

According to a 2024 report by Maersk, 76% of respondents reported experiencing supply chain disruptions, and a startling 58% of them reported that the costs exceeded their predictions. From sudden tariff changes that reshape sourcing decisions to unexpected raw material shortages or port closures, disruptions no longer come one at a time as they overlap, compound, and evolve faster than traditional planning tools can respond.

In this environment, organisations need more than data visibility. They need decision intelligence systems that can sense change, learn continuously, and act responsibly in real time. This cannot be achieved in isolation, and an ecosystem or network play is a must. This is also where the latest innovations in Artificial Intelligence, like Agentic AI, can help redefine supply chain resilience.

The role of Agentic AI in Supply Chain Resilience

Agentic AI has the potential to power the next evolution of intelligent supply chain management. Instead of waiting for analysts or planners to interpret data, AI agents can continuously monitor supply, logistics, and market signals and then autonomously simulate and recommend the best response.

A few scenarios include:

  • Sudden geopolitical tensions? AI agents instantly recalculate costs, identify alternate suppliers, and propose optimised procurement mixes.
  • An energy-price surge? AI agents can suggest shifting production to lower-cost facilities or off-peak hours to protect margins and emissions goals.

SAP and its partner ecosystem are harnessing the power of Agentic AI to bring the vision of an intelligent supply chain to life. As a strategic SAP partner, Fujitsu is at the forefront of this innovation - creating next-generation solutions that enhance visibility, resilience, and responsiveness across global value networks.

Among the many factors disrupting supply chains today, cross-border tariffs remain one of the most complex and persistent challenges. In this article, we explore how Fujitsu‚Äôs Agentic AI-driven offerings are designed to help businesses anticipate, adapt to, and overcome these disruptions - enabling a smarter, more connected, and future-ready supply chain.

Building a Resilient Supply Chain to respond to Trade disruptions

In recent months, global trade dynamics have become increasingly unpredictable. The rules that once made it easy for goods to flow across borders - like free trade agreements - are now being challenged by new tariffs, shifting political alliances, and unexpected disruptions across the trade lanes. In a recent study published by BCG in 2025, it is estimated that at least 20% to 30% of EBIT margins for companies across all manufacturing sectors are at risk from higher tariffs!

Real-World Example: How Agentic AI Transformed a Global Electronics Manufacturer

A leading global electronics manufacturer in Asia faced significant challenges stemming from supply chain uncertainties, siloed enterprise systems and fragmented data. Their complex IT landscape made it difficult to access and interpret critical information across departments, slowing down decision-making during high-stakes disruptions.

Traditional point-to-point data integration approaches would have taken years to unify these disparate systems. Instead, the company sought a transformative solution - one that could consolidate enterprise data, enrich it with industry and business context, and dramatically accelerate decision cycles.

Agentic AI proved pivotal in transforming the company‚Äôs response to disruptions.

During disruptions such as trade tariffs or natural disasters like earthquakes, the manufacturer needed to rapidly assess the impact across their supply chain. This required synthesising internal enterprise data with external sources such as demographic trends, trade data, and harmonised system (HS) codes to simulate scenarios and take informed action.

As part of a broader digital transformation initiative, the company explored how Agentic AI could address supply chain shortages. By deploying intelligent agents across multiple systems - procurement, sales, inventory, and orchestration - they enabled real-time data access and contextual decision-making. These agents were trained to perform specialised tasks and provide actionable recommendations to business users.

For example, in the case of a raw material shortage, agents could evaluate multiple alternatives:

  • Sourcing from an alternative supplier,
  • Adjusting production schedules based on material availability, or
  • Engaging with customers to reschedule orders while maintaining service levels.

Each scenario required granular simulation across millions of SKUs, factoring in product, customer, and supplier contexts. The orchestrator agent played a pivotal role by assessing each option through the lens of cost, priority, and service level, ultimately recommending the most optimal path forward.

This innovative use of Agentic AI not only enhanced agility and collaboration across the enterprise but also earned a global recognition. The World Economic Forum‚Äôs AI Governance Alliance acknowledged this solution as one of 18 advanced AI applications transforming business worldwide.

Turning Data into Decisions

Expanding data visibility across enterprise, market, and regulatory sources enhances predictive accuracy and resilience.

Some other examples of how companies can use data and smart technologies to solve supply chain challenges encountered in tariff change scenarios are as follows:

  • Profit and Cost Analysis: By mapping out where costs are rising due to tariffs, companies can decide whether to pass those costs on to customers, absorb them, or find cheaper alternatives.
  • Pricing Simulations: Businesses can test how different prices will affect demand and profits in different tariff scenarios, helping them find the best balance between staying competitive and making money.
  • Operational Changes: If a key supplier is hit by a new tariff, companies can quickly see what other options are available, compare costs and quality, and make a switch if needed.

Fujitsu‚Äôs Multi-AI Orchestration Platform

Fujitsu has developed a Multi-AI agent orchestration platform for use cases such as Profit Margin & Cost Analysis that can leverage data stored in both SAP and non-SAP systems to present specific scenarios that can impact a customer‚Äôs supply chain. Using the simulation capabilities of this offering, multiple scenarios can be developed and compared, and the right strategy can be devised. The agentic AI platform leverages the data and helps to implement the decisions back into SAP applications like SAP S/4HANA SAP Integrated Business Planning and SAP Digital Manufacturing to effectuate the optimal plan chosen earlier. In the future, these agents could be extended to support SAP Business Network Supply Chain Collaboration and Supply Chain Orchestration as well.

These offerings are also complementary to the AI innovations delivered by SAP with the Business Suite e.g. seamless access with Joule, enhanced collaboration and decision making with SCM agents, etc.

Preparing for an AI-Enabled Future

Introducing technological capabilities isn‚Äôt enough. Companies also need to change the way they work with AI. This includes:

  • Cultivating an ‚ÄúAI-first‚Äù mindset: AI projects executed with a traditional mindset rarely deliver transformative outcomes. A transformational mindset is required to transform supply chains with AI. A few key aspects are as follows:
    • Myths like ‚ÄúAI will completely replace humans‚Äù are making way to ‚ÄúAI agents will work alongside humans‚Äù. But accepting this at an individual level requires humans to trust AI.
    • Especially within the supply chain, one cannot afford to have unreliable supply chain plans or manufacturing schedules. Balancing the level of AI autonomy with human empowerment is key to gaining this trust.
    • An AI-first and transformational mindset is required in transforming supply chains with AI
  • AI upskilling: Technologies such as Generative AI are being widely used by people to simplify their personal tasks. However, when it comes to corporate use of such tools, there are several nuances that we need to be aware of, like trusted tools, enterprise context and security concerns. These also apply specifically to the use of AI in supply chains
  • Improve Network relationships: A supply chain network includes partners like component suppliers, logistics partners etc. These partners are important to ensure optimal running of the supply chain in normal times and become critical during disruptions. Trusted data sharing, clear communication channels, and robust digital capabilities are critical to sustaining a resilient partner ecosystem

Conclusion

Agentic AI is redefining how organisations anticipate, adapt, and act amid global supply chain volatility. Fujitsu and SAP‚Äôs joint innovation demonstrates that the future of supply chain resilience lies not just in data, but in intelligent, autonomous collaboration.

Learn More

If you‚Äôd like to see how such technology can be turned into a solution in action or to learn more, consider attending the Fujitsu ActivateNow event in Singapore.

entry.title: Release Highlights of advanced Available-To-Promise (aATP) in SAP Cloud ERP, Private Edition 2025
entry.content:
Order Promising plays a pivotal role in connecting supply chain planning‚Äîdriven by SAP Integrated Business Planning‚Äîwith execution in SAP Cloud ERP, across the order-to-cash process. Advanced ATP (aATP) in SAP ERP Private Cloud remains the flagship solution, delivering real-time, constraint-based order confirmations that enhance supply chain performance and ensure reliable customer commitments.

Figure 1 : Key functionalities of advanced ATP

With the 2025 FPS0 release, SAP has addressed several highly requested customer requirements for advanced ATP. Key enhancements in this release include consolidation of shipping locations during Alternative-Based Confirmation, package size consideration in availability checks, greater flexibility for manual confirmation adjustments, length-based ATP for the cable industry, and characteristics evaluation during availability checks‚Äîdelivering critical capabilities to support complex business needs.

Let‚Äôs do a deep dive into some of the key capabilities.

Consolidation of Shipping Locations

When customers order products available in partial quantities across multiple distribution centers or stock-holding locations, Alternative-Based Confirmation(ABC) now enables consolidation into a single location through automated creation of internal stock transport orders, ensuring one streamlined shipment instead of multiple ones.

Figure 2: Distributed fulfilment with Alternative-Based Confirmation (ABC)

Figure 3: Consolidated fulfilment with ABC with automated creation of Stock Transport Orders (STO)

This is especially valuable in export processes, where goods must be consolidated at the most suitable location for tariff, tax declaration, or letter-of-credit handling. The process reduces manual effort in creating stock transport documents, improves delivery date accuracy, and enhances compliance with export regulations. By optimizing logistics, it minimizes complexity, enhances customer satisfaction, and ensures efficient, legally compliant global shipping operations.

You can enable the automated creation of STOs during the process of Alternative Based Confirmation in ABC strategy.

Figure 4 ‚Äì Alternative-Based Confirmation with Stock Transport Document Creation

Unrestricted checks in Interactive Backorder Processing

Interactive Backorder Processing (IBOP) enables order fulfillment managers to adjust confirmations in real time based on business priorities. During unplanned supply shortages, scheduled Backorder Processing runs may be too late to resolve issues. IBOP provides flexibility to manually redistribute or modify confirmations for selected requirements, ensuring critical demands are met. The tool offers contextual information to support informed decision-making. Order fulfillment managers can also override constraints such as Product Allocation and Supply Protection in exceptional cases, addressing escalated business needs. This capability is invaluable during supply chain disruptions, empowering managers to respond quickly, reduce delays, and maintain customer satisfaction. 

Figure 5 ‚Äì Interactive Backorder Processing with Unrestricted checks

Order confirmation based on packaging size

Many businesses sell products in predefined package sizes, such as cartons of 24 cans or boxes of 20 packs. The enhanced availability check feature helps align orders with these packaging rules by automatically rounding requested quantities to the nearest valid unit, like full pallets, pallet layers, or cases, based on set rounding profiles, and rounding down confirmed quantities to meet packaging and transportation constraints. Business Add-In can also be used to incorporate custom rounding logic.

Figure 6 ‚Äì Rounding in aATP

This approach makes order quantities realistic from the start, reducing the need for manual corrections or late changes. The result is improved process efficiency, smoother execution, fewer errors, and enhanced customer satisfaction through reliable and accurate deliveries.

Characteristics evaluation in Supply creation-Based Confirmation

Supply creation-Based Confirmation (SBC) integrates aATP with PP/DS to confirm sales orders by triggering production when supply is insufficient, considering both finite capacity and component availability. The latest release also incorporates CDP characteristics during confirmation‚Äîcrucial for mill industries that plan, and produce based on product attributes and rely on block planning over production resources.

Length based availability check

Cable industries often sell products based on length, making precise availability checks critical. The length based-availability check in Supply creation-Based Confirmation (SBC) ensures that a single coil contains the required minimum length to meet an order. For example, if a customer needs a 1000m steel cable, the system only confirms it if a coil of at least 1000m is available‚Äîsmaller coils adding up to 1000m cannot be used. Once validated, ATP can trigger a cutting order, or in case of shortages, initiate production. This capability helps industries match customer requirements exactly, avoid unusable inventory, integrate tightly with production, and ensure reliable delivery commitments.

Figure 7: Length based ATP with Supply creation-Based Confirmation

That‚Äôs not all. Supply Protection has been enhanced to resolve overprotection and other critical issues causing unexpected results in sales order confirmations. New rating attributes in Alternative-Based Confirmation are added to simplify the maintenance of supersession chains. Enhanced Business Add-Ins provide greater flexibility to meet custom requirements‚Äîallowing modification of substitution results in ABC, insertion or manipulation of requirements, and advanced sorting in Backorder Processing, etc.

These are just a few highlights from the wide range of new enhancements in Order Promising in SAP Cloud ERP Private Edition. With a strong roadmap focused on AI and Analytics, future releases will continue to deliver next-generation capabilities to meet evolving customer needs.

entry.title: Building Sustainable Supply Chains: From Design to Reuse
entry.content:
Building Sustainable Supply Chains: From Design to Reuse

Sustainability is no longer just a nice-to-have; it‚Äôs a business must. Customers, regulators, and investors expect companies to take responsibility not only for their own operations but also for the environmental and social impact across their entire supply chain. That‚Äôs where the concept of double materiality comes in: it examines both how sustainability risks and opportunities affect a company's financial performance and how its activities impact society and the environment.

The challenge? Supply chains are sprawling, multi-tiered networks that cross industries, continents, and regulatory systems. But within this complexity lies opportunity. With the right strategy, processes, and technology, companies can build supply chains that are not only resilient and compliant but also drivers of long-term value.

In this blog, we‚Äôll explore how organizations can move step by step‚Äîfrom design to reuse‚Äîtowards building truly sustainable supply chains, and we‚Äôll highlight some of the SAP solutions that make this transformation possible.

Why Sustainable Supply Chains Matter

Supply chains are at the heart of the sustainability challenge. In industries such as automotive, consumer goods, and manufacturing, they can account for the majority of a company‚Äôs carbon footprint. Scope 3 emissions, encompassing those from suppliers, logistics, and product use, can account for more than 70% of a company's total greenhouse gas (GHG) impact.

And carbon is just one piece of the puzzle. Companies must also navigate regulatory requirements, such as EUDR and CBAM, improve resource efficiency, reduce waste, and prepare for climate-related risks, including water shortages and flooding. It sounds daunting, but within this complexity lies a real opportunity.

Think of the supply chain as a circle rather than a straight line:

  • Design sets the stage. Choices about materials, packaging, and product life cycles determine environmental impact long before anything is produced.
  • Plan and Procure shape how responsibly resources are sourced and how suppliers are engaged in meeting sustainability goals.
  • Manufacture is about efficiency and using less energy and water, generating less waste, and embedding circular practices into production.
  • Delivery focuses on logistics: reducing emissions in transportation, optimizing routes, and rethinking packaging.
  • The product usage shifts the spotlight to the customer, where durability, repairability, and energy efficiency influence both sustainability and satisfaction.
  • Reuse closes the loop through recycling, remanufacturing, or creating entirely new business models around product-as-a-service.

 

This circular approach transforms sustainability from a compliance exercise into a growth engine. Companies that weave sustainability into every step of their supply chain can cut costs, win customer trust, unlock new markets, and build resilience against disruptions.

Smart Design, Lower Impact

Take the example of a car seat. Sustainability starts in the design phase: the choice of materials, say eco-friendly upholstery instead of leather, has an immediate impact on the product‚Äôs footprint. In fact, leather use can trigger regulatory requirements in certain markets, such as the EU Deforestation Regulation (EUDR) compliance in Europe. Beyond materials, the way the seat is designed also matters. A seat that‚Äôs easy to disassemble makes it simpler to recycle components or reuse some material later, extending its lifecycle.

This is where technology comes in. SAP Responsible Design and Production helps manufacturers anticipate future Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) fees, giving them the insight to make smarter design and packaging decisions upfront. Meanwhile, SAP Green Token offers chain-of-custody transparency for certified sustainable and recycled materials, providing the credibility companies need to back sustainability claims, including compliance with regulations like EUDR.

In addition, with SAP Product and REACH Compliance, manufacturers can assess and document the environmental compatibility and regional marketability of their products.

From Cost to Carbon: Why Supply Chain Planning Needs a Sustainability Upgrade

Supply chain planning has traditionally focused on three things: cost, availability, and quality. But today, there‚Äôs a new non-negotiable: sustainability. Take the former example of a car seat: if the design calls for leather, then in Europe that leather must be EUDR-certified. Certifications like this shouldn‚Äôt be seen as an afterthought; they need to carry the same weight in planning as cost or quality.

And it goes beyond compliance. In the past, planners compared scenarios to find the best margins or service levels. Now, the question is just as much about impact: Which scenario delivers the lowest carbon footprint?

Smarter planning naturally leads to less waste. Optimizing inventory and capacity not only improves efficiency and saves money, but it also reduces emissions, creating better outcomes for both the business and the planet.

For global manufacturers, this matters even more. Europe requires EUDR-certified leather, while other markets may not. By weaving sustainability into planning, companies can stay compliant in every region without sacrificing efficiency.

This is where solutions like SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP) make a difference. IBP allows companies to embed sustainability into every step in the process, treating certifications as sustainability attributes, simulating emissions across scenarios, and flagging ESG risks before they escalate.

The bottom line: Future-proof supply chains don‚Äôt just balance cost and service; they balance cost, service, compliance, and environmental impact.

Procurement as a Catalyst for Sustainability

Procurement isn‚Äôt just about negotiating the best price or ensuring materials arrive on time; it's also about managing risk and optimizing supply chain efficiency. Every buying decision has a ripple effect on a company‚Äôs sustainability footprint, making procurement one of the most powerful levers for driving meaningful change.

Suppliers are validated based on their overall risk profile. This does include their exposure to climate change-related risks, their mitigation strategies, certifications, and overall sustainability performance. In our example of EUDR-certified leather, it is about the validation that the leather has not been produced by farms with deforestation practices. In addition, suppliers are requested to share the carbon footprint of their products, the calculation method, and potentially assurance documents. The capability of exchanging sustainability data, such as scope 3 emission data, across the value chain becomes crucial for collaboration to hit greenhouse targets. Analyzing the carbon footprint of different material choices allows companies to make informed sourcing decisions and balance cost, quality, and sustainability.

SAP offers multiple solutions to help customers. Embedding sustainability attributes into the risk assessment using SAP Ariba Supplier Risk helps to manage climate-related risks. Using SAP Sustainability Data Exchange supports a standardized and certified way to exchange sustainability data, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management calculates and analyzes emissions tied to product purchases, transportation, and manufacturing, and finally, SAP Green Token helps companies to be compliant with EUDR regulations.

When procurement leaders embrace these tools and practices, they move from simply buying materials to actively driving decarbonization and ensuring compliance. Sustainable buying isn‚Äôt a ‚Äúnice to have‚Äù anymore; it‚Äôs a game-changer for business and the planet.

Beyond Compliance: Embedding Sustainability Into Manufacturing Operations

Once raw materials arrive at the factory floor, the responsibility shifts from sourcing to production. At this stage, manufacturers face a critical challenge: how to minimize energy use, conserve water, cut waste, ensure worker safety, and stay compliant with evolving regulations.

Sustainable manufacturing isn‚Äôt just about checking boxes; it‚Äôs about embedding smarter processes that strengthen resilience and competitiveness. Here‚Äôs how leading companies are approaching it:

  • Energy and emissions tracking: By modeling energy flows across production lines, manufacturers can allocate emissions directly to activities and products, providing the transparency required to develop and track decarbonization strategies.

  • Waste reduction: Cradle-to-grave waste management and recycling programs help eliminate inefficiencies and reduce environmental impact.

  • Worker health and safety: Predictive tools highlight potential hazards, while real-time tracking improves visibility into incidents and ensures safer working conditions.

Take upholstery manufacturing as an example. By modeling the energy flow of a production line, businesses can calculate the carbon footprint of each unit produced. This not only enables accurate product-level sustainability reporting but also highlights where efficiency gains can be made.

To enable this shift, technology plays a vital role. SAP solutions help manufacturers close the loop:

  • #SAP Environment Management monitors emissions, waste, and compliance across operations

  • #SAP Workplace Safety strengthens incident visibility and fosters a culture of safety

  • SAP Sustainability Footprint Management  calculates product footprints based on measured data for transparent reporting

When done right, sustainable manufacturing reduces risk, ensures compliance, and delivers products with smaller footprints, turning sustainability into a competitive advantage.

Sustainable Logistics: Reducing Emissions Beyond the Factory Gate

Once a product leaves the factory, its journey has only just begun. Trucks, ships, and planes carry it across regions and continents, but these movements come at a cost. The logistics and distribution phase is one of the biggest contributors to supply chain emissions. The good news? Smarter delivery models are proving that it‚Äôs possible to move goods efficiently while shrinking environmental impact. 

It starts with transportation optimization. By consolidating shipments, reducing empty miles, and adopting low-carbon fuels, companies can cut unnecessary emissions while saving costs.  Just as important is knowing how much carbon is being released. By tracking emissions from different types of transport and sharing that information with customers, companies can be more transparent, helping customers to make better, more eco-friendly decisions. 

Collaboration plays a powerful role, too. By sharing carbon footprint data with customers and partners, manufacturers can build trust and enable joint action. For example, the automotive supplier calculates the full carbon footprint of the car seats from the material used, the inbound transport of those materials, through manufacturing energy use, to outbound delivery. The results are shared with OEM partners via Catena-X, creating a shared foundation for decarbonization across the value chain.

Technology is what makes these advances scalable:

  • SAP Transportation Management optimizes routing and freight networks, reducing both emissions and costs.

  • SAP Sustainability Footprint Management calculates carbon emissions, including scope 3.1 as well as logistics-based emissions such as scope 3.4 and 3.9 categories.

  • SAP Sustainability Data Exchange enables transparent and secure sharing of carbon data across networks

By embedding sustainability into logistics, companies can reduce costs, meet rising customer expectations, and support Scope 3 reporting, all while ensuring their products reach the right place at the right time with a lighter footprint.

Closing the Loop: How Circular Supply Chains Create New Value

The final stage of a product‚Äôs life cycle isn‚Äôt really the end; it‚Äôs the beginning of a new cycle. That‚Äôs the power of circular supply chains: they extend product life, recover valuable resources, and dramatically cut waste. It starts with managing and auditing waste streams responsibly, making sure even hazardous materials are handled the right way. From there, recycled inputs can be looped back into production, reducing the need for virgin resources and shrinking the footprint of every product made. Partnerships with recyclers and waste handlers play a big role too, creating steady, sustainable flows of materials that companies can depend on. But one of the most powerful strategies is remanufacturing and reuse. By reusing components and remanufacturing products closer to home, companies recover higher value while cutting both costs and emissions tied to sourcing and logistics. This approach strengthens ties with suppliers and gives both providers and customers a chance to reduce waste and build more sustainable products together. In our example, car seat fabrics might not just be made from recycled plastics supplied by disposal companies, but also combined with cork-based materials to meet demand, lowering reliance on new resources while delivering products that customers want. SAP helps bring these strategies to life.  SAP Environment, Health, and Safety Management ensures compliance and auditing of waste streams, SAP Integrated Business Planning balances demand and supply for recycled inputs, and SAP Waste and Recycling makes it easier to collaborate with recyclers and waste handlers. The impact speaks for itself: car seat manufacturers, adopting circular supply chain practices, have cut carbon emissions by 52% through smarter routing and sustainable materials, reduced per-seat emissions by 34%, and made emissions reporting 75 times faster. Circular supply chains don‚Äôt just close the loop; they create new opportunities for efficiency, savings, and competitive advantage. The final stage is not the end but the beginning of a new cycle. Circular supply chains extend product life, recover resources, and reduce waste.

Conclusion: The Future of Supply Chains Is Sustainable, Digital, and Circular

Sustainable supply chains are no longer a niche initiative. They are central to regulatory compliance, market differentiation, and long-term resilience. By embedding sustainability from design to reuse, organizations can cut carbon emissions and waste, ensure compliance with global regulations, build stronger supplier and customer relationships, and unlock entirely new circular business models. Technology is the enabler. With SAP'sSustainabilitysolutions,  companies can move beyond fragmented initiatives to an integrated, data-driven approach that turns sustainability into a growth engine.
 
As Can √úst√ºnberk, Executive Board Member at MarturFompak International, puts it: ‚ÄúWe are working passionately to adapt emerging technologies to all of our business processes and to create a ‚ÄòNew Digital and Sustainable‚Äô business model‚Äîto make it more resilient, more competitive, and above all to create a more Sustainable World.‚Äù
The future of supply chains is sustainable, digital, and circular. The companies that act decisively today will be the leaders of tomorrow.
 
This blog has explored how organizations can transform their supply chains step by step, from design to reuse, and how SAP solutions can make that transformation a reality.

entry.title: SAP‚Äôs New Logistics Management Module: A Cloud-Native Approach to Smarter Regional Supply Chains
entry.content:
At SAP Connect 2025 in Los Angeles, SAP unveiled a number of innovations in the supply chain space and one of the most notable is SAP Logistics Management, a new cloud-native solution designed to streamline and unify logistics operations  across warehouses, transportation, and logistics partners.

This launch reflects SAP‚Äôs strategy to simplify logistics for distributed and regional operations while enabling real-time visibility, automation, and collaboration across the supply chain network.

In this blog post, I will take you through what the module is, what its capabilities are, how it fits into the SAP ecosystem, and what it means for companies looking to modernise their logistics operations and all within one intelligent cloud platform.

Read the full blog to explore features, business impact, and practical steps to prepare your logistics operations for the next generation of SAP innovation.

What Is SAP Logistics Management?

SAP Logistics Management is a modern SaaS-based logistics solution built on the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).
It brings together warehousing, transportation management, and partner collaboration in a single, integrated system ‚Äî particularly suited for regional or satellite operations  while connecting seamlessly with SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Business Network.

Key Attributes

  • Cloud-native: Designed for seamless scalability, continuous innovation, and rapid deployment.
  • Unified logistics approach: Combines warehouse, transport execution, orchestration, and partner collaboration into one platform.
  • Native ERP integration: Connects easily with SAP Cloud ERP and SAP S/4HANA without heavy customisation.
  • Carrier & partner collaboration: Built-in connectivity through the SAP Business Network for real-time visibility and data sharing.
  • AI-powered operations (Joule): Leverages SAP Joule AI assistants to automate tasks, guide decisions, and reduce manual workload.

In short, SAP Logistics Management doesn‚Äôt replace heavy-duty logistics systems like SAP EWM or SAP TM, but rather extends SAP‚Äôs portfolio with a lighter, agile, intelligent logistics layer ideal for regional warehouses and distributed networks.
