Benefits & Business Value

Adopting SAP Logistics Management can deliver both operational and strategic gains:

  1. Reduced operational friction: Unified logistics reduces manual handoffs and integration gaps.
  2. Faster deployment for regional nodes: Cloud-native architecture enables quicker rollouts and lower implementation costs.
  3. Improved visibility & collaboration: Real-time tracking and partner integration enhance transparency and agility.
  4. AI-driven decision support: Joule AI assists planners, automates routine actions, and reduces human error.
  5. Scalable, modular growth: Deploy gradually across logistics nodes without disrupting existing core systems.
  6. Resilient and agile operations: Respond faster to disruptions and maintain consistent service levels.
  7. Network consistency: Standardised processes and data across multiple logistics layers ensure global alignment.

Key Challenges & Considerations

While promising, success depends on thoughtful execution.
Organisations should anticipate and plan for:

  • Scope & complexity limits: The module is optimised for low-to-medium complexity; large hubs may still need EWM + TM.
  • Data integration & master data quality: Consistent, clean master data is critical for seamless performance.
  • Change management: AI-driven workflows require user adoption and training.
  • Phased rollout strategy: Identify pilot nodes and migration paths carefully.
  • Carrier & partner readiness: True collaboration depends on network adoption.
  • Monitoring & exception handling: Maintain human oversight during early automation phases.
  • Cost vs. ROI alignment: Evaluate expected efficiency gains against investment costs.

 

What Businesses Should Do Next

If your organization already runs SAP Cloud ERP or S/4HANA, this launch presents a real opportunity to modernise logistics without starting from scratch.

Recommended Next Steps

  • Map your logistics footprint: Identify which regional or satellite nodes would benefit most.
  • Start with pilot deployments: Test configurations, training, and ROI in smaller sites.
  • Ensure data readiness: Clean up and harmonize master data across materials, locations, and partners.
  • Engage carriers early: Align carriers and logistics partners with the collaboration network from the start.
  • Plan coexistence: Integrate with existing EWM/TM during the transition phase.
  • Adopt AI in stages: Roll out automation features gradually and monitor outcomes.
  • Track KPIs from day one: Measure order throughput, dock utilisation, exception rates, and on-time delivery.

Conclusion 

The introduction of SAP Logistics Management marks a pivotal step in SAP‚Äôs supply chain evolution - moving toward networked, intelligent, and modular logistics.

With its cloud-native architecture, AI-powered automation, and embedded collaboration, it offers a compelling value proposition for companies with multi-tier logistics footprints.

Ultimately, success will depend on data readiness, partner engagement, and phased adoption but for organisations ready to embrace intelligent logistics, SAP is clearly paving the way for smarter, more connected supply chains.

Thank you for reading.

entry.title: Reimagining Logistics for the Cloud Era ‚Äî Inside SAP Logistics Management
entry.content:
Many small and mid-sized companies still depend on siloed systems: an old WMS here, spreadsheets for transportation, and emails for carrier updates. The result? Disconnected visibility, inefficiency, and rising logistics cost.

SAP Logistics Management (LGM) reimagines this landscape.
Built natively on the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), LGM unifies warehousing, transportation, and network collaboration into a single intelligent cloud platform. It brings the power of SAP EWM, SAP TM, and SAP Business Network for Logistics (BN4L) together for the first time in a cloud-native experience.

Solution Overview ‚Äî Unified, Scalable, and Built for the Cloud

SAP Logistics Management bridges execution gaps by bringing every logistics function into a unified flow: from goods receipt to shipment confirmation, across multiple warehouses, modes, and carriers.

Source: 4577_SAP_Logistics_Management_L2_Public

Cloud-nativeSaaS architecture, auto-updates, minimal IT footprint.
Unified logistics layerIntegrates warehouse, transport, and carrier collaboration.

Composable & scalableAdopt modules progressively (start small, scale fast).

Functional Scope ‚Äî From Warehouse to Network

SAP LGM delivers four main functional pillars:

  1. Warehouse Logistics (cloud EWM capabilities)

  2. Transportation Logistics (cloud TM capabilities)

  3. Network Collaboration (integrated with BN4L)

  4. Unified Planning & Control (real-time visibility cockpit)

Each pillar comes with its own set of Fiori apps, use cases, and business value.

Warehouse Logistics ‚Äî Cloud EWM Simplified

Warehouse Logistics in LGM handles end-to-end inbound, internal, and outbound warehouse operations. Designed for ease of adoption, it provides structured receiving, storage, and dispatch processes with mobile execution and embedded analytics ‚Äî all running in the cloud.

Warehouse Monitor App: Imagine a retailer‚Äôs regional warehouse receiving 200 SKUs per day. The supervisor uses Warehouse Monitor to see that Putaway Zone B is overloaded while Zone C is idle. Within seconds, tasks are rebalanced to maintain service levels ‚Äî no need for spreadsheets.

Unified Planning & Control ‚Äî Visibility in One View

The Unified Planning & Control cockpit serves as the command centre for logistics execution. It integrates data from warehousing, transportation, and network collaboration into one consolidated dashboard, allowing real-time monitoring and decision-making.

entry.title: Data quality comes at a price - also in in hospitals and clinics
entry.content:
Source: generated by Google Gemini

Initial situation

Data quality plays an essential role in virtually all core processes in hospitals and clinics, whether in medication, patient care, or supply logistics. In addition, data quality is not only an operational necessity, but also vital to compliance with regulations and laws (e.g., traceability of drugs or implants).

‚ÄúGarbage in = garbage out‚Äù

This makes it all the more important for every hospital or clinic to be aware of the importance of efficient data management.

In reality, however, there are many challenges in this area because the historically grown and often very heterogeneous system landscape with numerous clinical systems, ERP systems, and additional applications makes centralized and uniform data management difficult. In terms of data quality, it should be added that master data in particular must be maintained and distributed with a great deal of effort, often manually, which leads to the undesirable situation of poor-quality master data entering the clinical systems (‚Äúgarbage in‚Äù) and the resulting transaction data in the form of prescriptions, services, or consumption (‚Äúgarbage out‚Äù) being transferred from the systems to the ERP system.

This leads to numerous operational problems, whether in the supply logistics of medicines, medical products, and consumables for patients, suboptimal procurement of these operationally essential goods, or ultimately in rejections by health insurance companies due to incorrect service invoices.

Way out

Anyone who believes that the use of new technologies or new tools such as AI will solve the problems described above is likely to be bitterly disappointed. Instead, what is needed is the establishment of a centrally managed and organizationally strong data management system with the aim of creating a new awareness of a ‚Äúdata-centric‚Äù orientation within the organization.

What are the most important factors for successful data management to ensure data quality?

  1. Golden source: The principle is one ‚Äúgolden source‚Äù per data area or data object. Ideally, there is only one system (e.g., data warehouse, master data management) in the target architecture as the leading system or ‚Äúgolden source.‚Äù In practice, however, this is not always feasible due to the system landscape and its history and complexity, because the implementation does not justify the expected benefits due to the anticipated costs and implementation time. It is therefore much more important to mandatorily always define one leading system or one ‚Äúgolden source‚Äù per data area or data object.
  2. Validation: Data quality can be ensured most easily and efficiently at the source or during data generation. With suitable validation rules, necessary technical (e.g., pharmaceutical validation of drugs) and technical (e.g., duplicate checking) rules can be checked. This is the only way to prevent ‚Äúbad‚Äù data from entering the system in the first place.
  3. Automation: Unfortunately, manual data entry or data mutations of any kind are a frequent cause of operational inefficiencies, loss of data quality, and, last but not least, great frustration for data users. The maxim is therefore: as little manual intervention as possible in data transfer or data distribution, but maximum data automation via suitable interfaces, including monitoring and, if necessary, error messages (alerting).
  4. Quality assurance: In practice, actual quality assurance is often neglected because employees are often busy with manual or semi-automated data tasks and do not have the time for quality assurance. First, the data management challenges described above must be solved so that, in the next stage of data maturity, quality assurance with corresponding quality reports or KPIs can be achieved. However, once these control mechanisms for data quality have been implemented, quality problems can be identified much earlier (e.g., data records with missing batch information for implants) and more proactively (e.g., incorrect data records in service billing), and appropriate measures can be taken. Added to this are the possibilities offered by AI to apply increasingly intelligent control mechanisms.

Source: own illustration

Conclusion

Data quality is not a ‚Äúsure-fire success‚Äù and comes at a price. However, this is less about implementing new IT systems and IT tools and more about organizational awareness of the importance of professional data management. Otherwise, the old adage ‚Äúgarbage in = garbage out‚Äù will remain true, resulting in costly operational inefficiency and a lack of potential for more digitized and data-driven processes.

entry.title: Supply Chain Planning Reimagined: Charting the Path to Decision-Centric, Autonomous Planning
entry.content:
For decades, supply chain leaders have been on a relentless quest for greater efficiency. We've built global networks, mastered lean inventory, and embraced automation at breakneck speeds. But the last few years have upended comfortable certainties. Geopolitical upheaval, pandemic ripple effects, and climate-related disruptions have rewritten the rules‚Äîturning volatility into the new normal. Today, planning is no longer a periodic exercise; it‚Äôs a dynamic, always-on process at the heart of business resilience and agility.

To empower confident and resilient planning companies need to synchronize decision-making across end-to-end supply chains, and drive sustainable value through data science, AI-powered insights, and transformative, outcomes-centric processes.

The Challenge: Confronting Complexity and Persistent Change

Supply chain leaders face an environment defined by persistent uncertainty. Plans must change not by quarter or by month‚Äîbut sometimes by hour. Yet too many organizations are still hampered by legacy silos and fragmented tools, resulting in disjointed planning, slow decision cycles, and out-of-date data. The pressure to keep peace and indeed to anticipate disruption has never been greater.

The journey from data to action is often bogged down in manual handoffs, conflicting KPIs, and limited scenario planning, limiting the impact of even the best talent and intentions.

By connecting these capabilities, companies can create a unified workspace designed with planners in mind to anticipating risk, managing by exception, and relentlessly driving better outcomes.

Delivering Tangible Value: The Autonomous Advantage

What does this look like in measurable business impact?

SAP‚Äôs advanced planning platform is driving real results for companies worldwide:

  • Faster planning cycles so that teams that once updated plans weekly can now adapt in near real-time, reallocating resources in minutes rather than days.

Critically, this approach enables organizations not just to react faster, but to leap ahead, and to turn their supply chain from a cost center into a competitive differentiator.

Cultivating a Culture of Continuous Improvement

Adopting decision-centric, autonomous planning is more than a technology upgrade. It requires a fundamental shift in mindset: from reactive firefighting to proactive, empowered problem-solving.

The most successful teams are those that embrace change, foster collaboration, and encourage learning at every level.

At SAP, we strive to be a trusted partner on this journey, providing not just technology, but proven business templates, industry best practices, and a collaborative ecosystem. Our mission is to help planners and decision-makers become architects of resilience and agents of innovation in their organizations.

Charting the Path Forward

In today‚Äôs landscape, the only constant is change, and the urgency for more agile, intelligent supply chains is undeniable. The winners of tomorrow will be those who act today to unlock new levels of confidence, speed, and value creation through decision-centric, autonomous planning.

Whether you‚Äôre a seasoned supply chain executive or rising operations leader, now is the time to ask:

entry.title: The Future of Supply Chain Management | Part 1 of 6
entry.content:
Supply Chain 2035: How Future Supply Chain Management Works

More and more companies have recognized the critical power of supply chain management for business success ‚Äì without viable supply chains, there are no satisfied customers, no successful product launches, and no stable value creation. Supply chains need to continuously evolve to meet these needs. Today, digital technologies open up numerous opportunities, which you could only dream of a few years ago: more accurate forecasts, fully connected partner networks, and near-autonomous operations.

At the same time, the economic environment is changing at a rapid pace: geopolitical tensions, changing customer needs, and climate change pose additional challenges for companies. In ten years‚Äô time, supply chain management will look different than today ‚Äì more connected, data-driven, and more adaptable than ever before. But what exactly will change, and how can companies prepare for it today? To answer these questions, SAP Business Consulting and K√ºhne Logistics University conducted a comprehensive study last year, the results of which we present in today‚Äôs and the next five issues.

We are building on a previous study in which we analyzed the visions of the future of companies in the middle of the ‚ÄúDigital SC Hypes‚Äù ten years ago. The mood was euphoric: From numerous conversations with supply chain managers, over 120 potential use cases arose ‚Äì from 3D printed Lego stones to the use of social media data in sales forecasting to mini factories, ultra-fast BOM resolution, and last mile drone delivery. Companies were ready to invest and experiment with new technologies. Much was visionary, some sounded like science fiction ‚Äì and yet the digital revolution in supply chains seemed tangibly close.

Our follow-up study shows a significantly changed picture. Pragmatic realism has given way to the great euphoria. Over the last 10 years, many technologies have been introduced slower and to a lesser extent than expected. The reasons for this include underestimated complexity and misconceptions about the performance of digital solutions (e.g. augmented reality, 3D printing or IoT), as well as an often inadequate technological state of development in the companies. Often, immature technologies, talent shortages, and inconsistent data quality slowed down execution.

Of course, there were also some pioneers ‚Äì often from industries with high pressure to innovate ‚Äì who secure an advantage with targeted investments and know-how. Success often correlated with a focus on clearly outlined use cases with rapid return on investment: better delivery reliability, fewer disruptions, quickly tangible value for the user.

This has been further reinforced by the recent years of pandemic, geopolitical tensions and economic weaknesses. Digital solutions for increasing automation, building integrated planning platforms, or tools to improve the customer experience are now only introduced if their value is clearly demonstrated. Successful projects usually start small and are not scaled until they have a proven effect. Lack of data quality, talent shortages, and lack of system integration are some of the biggest hurdles. Consistent data and change management is indispensable.

Between 2015 and 2025, the view of digital technologies has changed significantly: away from technology-driven euphoria, towards a use-oriented deployment. The potential to achieve true competitive advantage with new technologies in supply chain management is enormous. However, many companies are still lagging behind technology leaders today.

As part of our study, several surveys were conducted with a total of approximately 660 supply chain experts to understand today‚Äôs situation and expectations for 2035. In a multitude of in-depth discussions on Plan, Source, Make, Deliver, and People, we identified measures that companies should implement immediately, regardless of the scenario.

There are some exciting insights for the 2035 supply chains. First, the foundation of any successful digital transformation is a significant improvement in data quality. Companies also need appropriate tools to leverage this data and not remain ‚Äúdata-rich but insights poor.‚Äù People will continue to be important in the future, but their roles are changing. When AI takes on most of the operational work, and employees primarily monitor and develop, they are responsible for tasks that they have never practically performed themselves. Value chain silos will disappear, and technology-driven planning enables seamless end-to-end control.

Few innovation leaders like Amazon, Apple or Procter & Gamble will be able to set new standards on their own. Most organizations do not have comparable budgets, skills, or talents. They will make technological leaps, especially if they can use market-based standard solutions and thus participate in developments.

Regardless of the individual level of maturity, it is possible to record: If you want to play at the front in 2035, you must already start implementing ‚Äúno-regret moves‚Äù: for example, establish robust data governance, standardize processes, and introduce employees specifically to AI tools. Companies that lay these foundations today will not only use technologies in 2035, but will use them strategically. Or, to say it with the words of Wayne Gretzky, ‚ÄúGood players skate to the puck. Great players skate to where the puck is going to be.‚Äú

In the second part of the series, we will show in the next issue why supply chain planning is becoming the decisive success factor, what gaps exist here today between ambition and reality, and how companies can prepare for 2035 with data, AI, and agents. In the subsequent expenditures, we will examine the key findings of our research in the areas of purchasing, production, distribution, and employees.

 

This article was written in collaboration with Prof. Kai Hoberg (K√ºhne Logistics University) and Florian Diehlmann (SAP) in the context of the SAP-KLU study "The Supply Chain of the Future‚Äù.
